concurrency

Class ThreadPool

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.util.concurrent.AbstractExecutorService
      • java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor
        • java.util.concurrent.ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor
          • concurrency.ThreadPool
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Closeable, java.lang.AutoCloseable, java.util.concurrent.Executor, java.util.concurrent.ExecutorService, java.util.concurrent.ScheduledExecutorService
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    SoundManager

    public class ThreadPool
extends java.util.concurrent.ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor
implements java.io.Closeable

    This class builts a pool of Threads. This pool can be used to do a lot of things at the same time. Allowing the time spend to decrease significantly. It allows datastructures to keep a list of tasks the Threads should do. It provides extra functionality for the ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor class as well as some methods to add functionality.

    The usage of this class is made easier to comfort the programmers that use it many times. ThreadPool is a more natural name, and it is a lot shorter than it's superclass.

    Furthermore the class contains some simple methods to help you along the way. It's methods are primary wrapper methods. By which is meant methods that simply call other methods already in existence and not changing them. This does however not exclude the adding of methods that take different parameters as arguments and use them.

    Since:
    6-8-2014
    Version:
    7-8-2014
    Author:
    stefanboodt
    See Also:
    Thread, Runnable, Callable, ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor, Future

      • ThreadPool

        public ThreadPool(int amount)
        Sets up a ThreadPool with the given amount of Threads.
        Parameters:

    • Method Detail

      • addTask

        public void addTask(java.lang.Runnable runner)
        Adds a task to the pool. It is equivalent to #submit(Runnable task, void). Since there can be a lot of situations in which you want a thread to simply run some code without returning anything you can call this method for convenience.
        Parameters:
        runner - The task you want to add.

      • addTask

        public java.util.concurrent.Future<?> addTask(java.lang.Object invoker,
                                              java.lang.reflect.Method method,
                                              java.lang.Object[] parameters)
                                       throws java.lang.IllegalAccessException,
                                              java.lang.IllegalArgumentException,
                                              java.lang.reflect.InvocationTargetException
        This method adds a new runnable to the end of the queue of tasks. It transforms the method into a runnable. Calling this method takes a lot of work away if
        Parameters:
        invoker - The object to invoke the method on. If the method is static this one doesn't matter.
        method - The method to invoke.
        parameters - The parameters of the method.
        Returns:
        a future object that is a representation of the calculation. The get method should be used to get it's return value.
        Throws:
        java.lang.reflect.InvocationTargetException - if the method throws an Exception
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the method is passed an Illegal value.
        java.lang.IllegalAccessException - If the method is unaccessable.

      • addImageLoadingTask

        public java.util.concurrent.Future<java.awt.Image> addImageLoadingTask(java.lang.String location)
        Adds a task to load an Image. This is done a lot of times by games and other applications that rely heavily on the loading of images.
        Parameters:
        location - The location the image is in.
        Returns:
        A future containing the image.

      • close

        public void close()
           throws java.io.IOException
        Closes the threadpool and kills all threads. It also clears the tasklist.
        Specified by:
        close in interface java.io.Closeable
        Specified by:
        close in interface java.lang.AutoCloseable
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if an IOException is thrown during clean up.
